{"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient is placed on deep vein thrombosis (DVT) prophylaxis as part of a routine protocol. The most common form of DVT prophylaxis is the use of anticoagulants, such as heparin or low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). Heparin and LMWH work by enhancing the activity of antithrombin III, which in turn inhibits several factors in the coagulation cascade, including factor X. Therefore, the factor most directly affected by the DVT prophylaxis in this case would be factor X.", "answer_choice": "C"}
